Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: The radar screen glowed in front of me, a web of green lines and blips. I coordinated with the controller in the next sector, making sure the aircraft on route 27 would cross over smoothly. My headset buzzed with chatter, and I scribbled notes, eyes darting between screens. But my mind kept drifting to my wallet, sitting on the kitchen counter at home. Today was the only morning I could grab my ID before work, and without it, I couldn’t vote tomorrow. The polling station was open, but my shift schedule left no other window. I felt the weight of responsibility—hundreds of lives depended on my focus, but so did my right to have a say in the election. My supervisor expected flawless coordination, no distractions. The polling officials expected me to show up with proper identification. I stared at the clock, heart pounding, torn between the demands of the airspace and the demands of my citizenship, knowing I couldn’t meet both at once.
